ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

ILLEGAL TRAWLING IN SERANGOON RIVER
AND THE JOHORE STRAITS


    1. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development and Communications whether he is aware of illegal trawling with boats powered by outboard motors in the Serangoon River and the Johore Straits which is seriously affecting the livelihood of fishermen in the area, and what steps he proposes to take to safeguard the livelihood of those fishermen.

    The Senior Minister of State for National Development (Dr Tan Eng Liang) (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, the Primary Production Department is aware of the illegal trawling activities in the Serangoon River and Johore Straits. The Primary Production Department with the assistance of the Marine Police, have been conducting enforcement action in this area. In 1976, the Department conducted a total of 55 operations. Four persons were arrested for illegal trawling along the Straits of Johore over the last three months, and legal proceedings are being instituted against them.

    As a deterrent measure, the Fisheries Act was amended in 1973 to provide mandatory jail sentence for illegal trawlers.

    The Department will continue to operate enforcement patrols against the illegal trawlers.

OTTER TRAWLING
(Expansion of)


    2. Mr Ng Kah Ting asked the Minister for National Development and Communications what measures he proposes to take to encourage the expansion of otter trawling and if his Ministry will consult with the Ministry of Defence with a view to stepping up patrols by the Republic of Singapore Navy to protect our otter

Column: 252

trawling fleet from harassment by pirates on the high seas in the vicinity of Horsburgh Lighthouse.

    Dr Tan Eng Liang (for the Minister for National Development and Communications): Mr Speaker, Sir, otter trawling is one of the methods of fishing used by our fishermen. The Primary Production Department is also encouraging the fishermen to use other methods of fishing. However, the expansion of otter trawling is limited due to the lack of fishing ground and the lack of interest among our youths to take up fishing as they do not like the difficult life at sea.

    The Primary Production Department used to run a Fisheries Training School with UNDP assistance. From a survey conducted on more than 100 trainees who have completed a one-year training course, only 8% were found to be employed on board fishing vessels. The Training School has been discontinued since June 1976.

    The Primary Production Department maintains close liaison with the Republic of Singapore Navy and the Marine Police on the protection of our fishing vessels against piracy. Naval vessels have been deployed to conduct anti-piracy patrols in the vicinity of Horsburgh Lighthouse. This has resulted in a reduction in the number of piracy incidents in the area. In 1975, there were 25 reported harassment cases. In 1976, only seven cases were reported.

PRESIDENT'S ADDRESS

Debate on the Address
(Fourth Day)


    Order read for Resumption of Debate on Question [14th February, 1977].

    `That the following Address in reply to the Speech of the President be agreed to:-

    "We, the Parliament of the Republic of Singapore, express our thanks to the President for the Speech which he delivered on behalf of the Government at the opening of the First Session Of this Parliament.".'-[Dr Chiang Hai Ding].

    Question again proposed.

2.35 p.m.

    Dr Augustine H. H. Tan (Whampoa): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have the dubious honour of bridging the years of the Dragon and the Snake. Fortunately, being a Dragon. I have no reason to be afraid of Snakes.

    When we last adjourned I was speaking about the economic difficulties in the advanced countries. To recapitulate briefly, there seems to be a slowing down of technological innovations which fuel the engine of economic growth. Secondly, the aging population structure in the industrial countries has altered the pattern of demand, necessitating rather painful and difficult changes in production patterns. Thirdly, there is the energy crisis which will bring about escalating costs of energy resulting in lower standards of living and contributing to

Column: 254

inflation. I might add two other important factors. One was raised by the President in his Address and by the Prime Minister's Addendum. This refers to the excessive cushioning of life by state subsidies to the point where incentives for work and enterprise are seriously eroded, with disastrous consequences in terms of unemployment, inflation and falling standards of living.

    The fifth factor contributing to the economic malaise of the industrial countries is that of over-education, referred to by the hon. Member for Ulu Pandan. Over half the 18-year old males in the advanced countries are receiving college education. And college graduates usually look for administrative and managerial jobs. Rapid economic growth up to the end of the sixties brought the job opportunities and the incentives for higher education. But the era of rapid growth is over unless new cheap energy sources are discovered. Consequently, executives and managerial positions are difficult to come by. At the same time, blue-collar jobs go a-begging. This naturally creates further problems of adjustment in the industrial countries.

    The lessons for us are painfully clear. Our educational system must be geared to economic realities. In an era of sluggish economic growth, we shall only be creating more frustrations if we produce graduates for whom few jobs are available.

    In America, President Carter has announced a fiscal stimulation package of US$31 billion to be implemented over two years. At the same time, he is urging the Japanese and the West Germans to stimulate their economies simultaneously. Unfortunately, the severe winter in America has disrupted production and increased fuel bills, thereby diluting the economic stimulus of the tax cut. Moreover, in my view, the fiscal measures will stimulate more consumption than investment. Hon. Members may know that Keynesian economists believe that a tax cut and/or increased government expenditure will produce growth and employment. A tax cut,

Column: 255

for example, makes more money available to individuals who will spend some of it and save the rest. Their spending will stimulate more production, both directly and via a multiplier effect. Factories therefore can utilize more of their capacity and at the same time employ more people. Those factories operating at full capacity are supposed to have incentive for expanding their operations, thus providing more jobs. But I do not believe in Keynesian economics. The main stimulus to investment comes from technological innovations which open up new frontiers of profitable opportunities. Investments in these new areas in turn stimulate investments in the established industries through the input-output relationship where one factory buys its requirements from other factories and in turn sells to others. Unfortunately we know too little about the processes of technological innovations and governments of the advanced countries have not yet identified this to be a priority area of attention. Consequently, I expect that, while growth rates in the industrial countries can be marginally improved, unemployment and inflation will continue to be severe problems.

    The problems in store for us are threefold. First of all, it will be harder for us to attract new foreign investments as unemployment conditions in the advanced countries will deter capital outflow, witnessed already by the vast volume of literature on multinational corporations, especially those emanating from the trade unions in the advanced countries where they are very much against the so-called export of jobs and technology to developing countries while we can expect the pressures to increase. Secondly, we may find it more difficult to export our goods if industrial countries raise their trade barriers to protect their own employment. Already we have seen the imposition of barriers by the European Common Market on our electronic calculators. This is a harbinger of things to come. Thirdly, higher energy costs mean higher transportation costs. Our imports and our exports incur transportation charges. Therefore, for all three reasons, we must expect to work harder to maintain and, if

Column: 256

possible, to improve our standards of living. Either we take the question of raising productivity seriously and urgently or we may find unemployment and erosion in our standards of living.

    In addition to the imperative of raising productivity we need greater efforts in export promotion. Export financing is being provided but other areas like marketing, product development, advertising and more importantly, after-sales service should be carefully studied. Further diversification into new markets like West Asia and expansion of markets in the ASEAN region will be helpful to reduce our vulnerability. However, we can only maintain our competitive edge by producing products and services of high quality at low cost and with the proper after-sales service. But if our manufacturers have only a very limited time horizon and are interested in one-shot deals and one-shot sales, then of course they will continue to market goods which are inferior in quality and will not bother to look after the consumers once they have sold their products.

    To encourage greater investment in manufacturing we should examine the incentives for expansion and diversification of existing industries. Since we are going to find it harder to attract new industries, this seems to be a logical thing to look into. Furthermore, we need to examine what additional technical and supporting facilities Government agencies can offer to stimulate private development, especially in those areas of industry where they find it very expensive to buy and maintain their own testing equipment and calibration equipment. But if such equipment can be provided by Government it will certainly help to stimulate such industries.

    The Ministry of Finance emphasized further development of manufacturing but perhaps in the protectionist era that we are entering, we should examine the feasibility of developing other service industries to ensure reasonable growth and full employment.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, Ministries usually inform this House of new programmes but we hear

Column: 257

too little by way of progress reports and objective evaluation of the success or failure of such programmes, for the Annual Reports submitted by Ministries and Statutory Boards are not of much help as they usually present glowing accounts and not critical analyses of work done by their agencies. I submit that what we need is more critical monitoring of what goes on.

2.45 p.m.

    Mr Lee Yiok Seng (Bukit Panjang)(In Mandarin): Mr Speaker, Sir, the President in his policy speech delivered at the opening of this Parliament said that:

    `This Government has the highest number of votes. This vote of confidence imposes a heavy responsibility on my Ministers to act fairly but firmly. My Government will exercise its authority to govern with circumspection and moderation.'

    This simple message has alleviated the fears of the people, because during the General Elections they heard a lot of empty promises made by the Opposition parties and a lot of criticisms have been levelled at the People's Action Party. Yet the electorate was intelligent enough to decide to support the People's Action Party. However, there are some people who worry about the eventuality that once the PAP is elected with full backing of the voters and with a higher percentage of votes this might result in the PAP Government being complacent and will therefore neglect the wishes, and needs of the people.

    However, from the policy speech delivered by the President, it is clear that the PAP Government will strive for excellence and will not be complacent over its achievements, nor will it abandon or neglect the people. The President also gave a piece of advice to the Government that the authority of the Government derives from the people and the Government should be concerned with the people's welfare and interests and that in exercising its power it should see that the people's interests are placed above all else. The greater the support given to the Government, the greater will be the

Column: 258

responsibility of the Government. Therefore, whether they be Ministers or Members of Parliament are in the service of the Government, they must set the good example of doing their best and in utilising their talent and attributes to carry out Government's policies, they should always be mindful of the interests and wishes of the people. They should try to understand the difficulties and needs of the people. A Minister should not only be concerned with his own Ministry or Constituency but should also be concerned with the well being of all the people of Singapore. As soon as any anomaly or aberration is discovered, he must see that the civil servants rectify it as soon as possible. For the sake of the nation and the people, the Ministers must not hesitate to admit their errors.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I am a Member representing the rural areas. It is therefore my duty to voice the opinions, the problems and the needs of the rural people. In the last few years the people in the rural areas faced various problems. Their needs also have to be satisfied. Our country is a rapidly developing one, attaching great importance to major problems of improvement and development. This has resulted in neglecting the problems in the rural areas or its importance lessened. A lot of problems in the rural areas have therefore been shelved resulting in an increase in the number of problems rather than reducing it because of the need for development. Therefore, when Members of Parliament representing the rural areas raise the same problems and needs, they are regarded as being conservative in their thinking. This is because the problems in the rural areas have not been solved, and not because the MPs are stubborn and conservative.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, in the last few years, there were developments and modernisation in many spheres. According to my observation, there must be special development programmes to institute modern amenities in the rural areas to compensate for their backwardness and to bridge the gap between the urban areas and the rural areas. The Government should

Column: 259

consider the early implementation of this scheme. I feel that in order to effectively tackle the problems of the rural areas a Rural Affairs Bureau should be set up by the Government to help tackle their problems.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I am sorry to say that in the various Addenda there is no mention of any new programmes or any projects for the provision of modern amenities for the rural areas. Our rural areas are still quite extensive and quite a large proportion of our population live in the rural areas. So it is the duty of the Government to do something for the people in the rural areas.

    I have some suggestions to make for the consideration of the Government. Firstly, in the field of education, schools in the rural areas are very small and poorly equipped. The teaching of the second language cannot reach the required standard. If this situation is not rectified, then the pupils from the rural schools who receive unequal training will not be able to compete fairly with children from the urban schools in future. Why does the Ministry of Education not consider this and try to solve this problem?

    Secondly, there is the problem of public transport. Most of the rural people live in areas quite removed from the major roads, some three or four miles away. They do not possess their own transport. They are in dire need of public transport service in their daily travel. If we approach this question fairly, we will see that the rural people have the greatest need for a public transport service. However, the Ministry of Communications has not done anything about it. Why is this so?

    Thirdly, in the field of public construction, most of the rural people are engaged in farming for a livelihood. They have to carry their farm produce to the city and elsewhere and bring back fertilisers and other supplies. They are therefore in pressing need of good public roads to facilitate their transport needs. With good roads, they will be able to raise the price of their produce and reduce their cost. As it is the maintenance of roads in the rural areas depends only on the very meagre annual allocation of funds by the

Column: 260

Urban and Rural Services Committee. If the Ministry of National Development does not amend the scheme, I would ask when will road construction works be completed in the rural areas?

    Fourthly, primary production. Many farmers in the Republic have been affected by resettlement schemes. They are asked to leave their farm land which the Government intends to develop. But the Government has not been able to help them in a satisfactory way and so they have to give up their farming activities in which they are good at in search of new means of livelihood. No doubt, the Government has allocated a piece of land in the Punggol area for pig rearing, but it is to be operated on a large scale. Small-scale farmers would not therefore have any chance to participate in the pig-rearing enterprise. Thus, they have to give up and look for other outlet.

    With regard to vegetable farmers, the Government has not been able to give them alternative land, and so they are forced to give up their farming occupation. For example, in my Constituency, many vegetable gardeners have been asked to leave. They will be evicted and they are worried about their future. I feel that vegetable gardeners have contributed a lot to the food supplies of our people. The Ministry of National Development should help them and give them alternative land so that they can continue with their usual vegetable gardening. I am sorry to note that the Ministry of National Development does not seem to think so.

    Fifthly, on the relationship between the civil servants and the rural people. Rural people lack a knowledge of Government administration or the setup of Government Departments. They are straightforward. honest, practical and pragmatic. Therefore, they are quite ignorant of and worried about Government processes and the notices which are given to them. They are at a loss over these matters. Civil servants also lack an understanding of the rural people. They do things by the rule and they follow instructions to the letter. Therefore, there exist a lot of

Column: 261

misunderstanding and dissatisfaction between the rural people and certain civil servants. In fact, civil servants should exercise certain flexibility in implementing Government policies or measures so as to achieve greater effectiveness. According to my observation over the years, in their official dealings with the people in the rural areas, civil servants have been very rigid in their attitude, very lacking in humane sentiment. Therefore, the rural people find it difficult to take and are disappointed with the Government. The crux of the problem is that the civil servants lack an understanding of the problems of rural areas and special training.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, the problems which I have mentioned above have not been satisfactorily solved for a long time neither has there been a systematic plan for solution. I feel that this is because the various Ministries are busy with their own important business and therefore neglecting the minor problems of the rural areas. I therefore feel that if the Government can establish a special department to give special assistance to the various departments in tackling rural problems, greater achievement will te obtained. Sir, I support the motion thanking the President.

3.00 p.m.

    Dr Ong Leong Boon (Kim Song): Mr Speaker, Sir, I rise to support the motion thanking the President for the speech he delivered on 8th February on behalf of the Government. It was an excellent speech with the message loud and clear; an instructive address with lots of punch and purpose, caution and exhortation. Aptly. Singaporeans expected no less. This is after all a no-nonsense political leadership that has enjoyed and continues to enjoy the fullest confidence of the people of Singapore.

    Going through the President's Address and the various Addenda. I must confess that I found very little to quarrel with. The plan of action for the various Ministries for the next five years takes us further on the road of

Column: 262

nation-building to make Singapore a more just and a more equal society. I have no doubts that, barring developments beyond our control, we shall succeed if we continue as a nation to show grit, stamina and hard work.

    The Addendum on the Prime Minister's Office emphasised the philosophy of the Government: that rewards must be correlated with work, that excellence should be rewarded and honoured in order that all can benefit from the exceptional talents of the few, that the talented few should not be punished to satisfy the doctrinal follies of the even fewer. We hold true the traditional Asian precept, "From each his best, to each his worth". It follows therefore that any flirtation with unrealistic doctrines is an exercise to kill human motivation and genius. At the same time the Government declared that it commits itself to help the needy through better education and health so that all men and women are equal in health and opportunities.

    Our philosophy reflects a deep understanding of the human nature, the id and the ego. We seek to motivate man to better himself to work hard, to reach for excellence in return for what he is worth, We see no virtue in dogma or doctrinaire politics, and we find the heavy-handed practice in some countries to methodically destroy man and his familiar surroundings to recreate a new man, an unacceptable and unnecessarily expensive exercise.

    The PAP, I am sure, shall continue to govern with circumspection and moderation, to jealously guard our national interests, to reject unhealthy influences that do us no good. To progress and to move ahead we must continue to selectively imbibe relevant factors of other societies, Western, Japanese or Chinese and "incorporate these factors into our system without damage to ourselves".

    I note with great interest the amount of debate and discussion the President's address has generated in this House over the last week. I am also extremely encouraged by the favourable response of the public to this

Column: 263

first session of the fourth Parliament. Obviously, Sir, MPs have taken note of the President's clarion call "to ensure that all shades of opinion out in the constituencies are vigorously voiced in Parliamentary questions and debates. No major policy or legislation should be passed without the closest scrutiny, and passed after the most thorough debate".

    It would appear to me as if Chairman Mao's call: "Let a hundred flowers blossom, and a thousand schools of thought contend" has come to town at last. This time we are happily reassured by the Leader of the House that no heads will roll as a consequence.

    Sir, as you know, unaccustomed as I am to scratching another's back, I must however give due credit to Dr Toh Chin Chye, Minister for Health and -

    Mr Speaker: Dr Ong, I wish you would refer to the hon. Member by his designation rather than his name.

    Dr Ong Leong Boon: Yes, Sir, I must give due credit to the hon. Member for Rochore and Minister for Health who first spoke out for more debate in 23rd December, 1976 his press interview after winning the Elections. That night, I think the hon. Member spoke his mind. The rest, as you know, is now history.

    An hon. Member: It was in the morning of 24th December.

    Dr Ong Leong Boon: Sir, we are a one-party Parliament through no fault of the PAP. As one of many nations with constitutionally elected governments, Singapore is unique in having a first-rate Government but an appalling collection of non-viable opposition parties outside Parliament that wake up every fifth year. The real opposition walked out of this House in 1963 and took to the streets. And lest they be forgotten, we are constantly and painstakingly reminded that they are very much around. And indeed they are.

    PAP Backbenchers are now expected to assume the role of the Parliamentary opposition: to debate issues, to air

Column: 264

grievances, to check and balance government action or inaction, to provide the forum for the government to explain and justify its policies and implementations. This, of course, presupposes that Ministers will co operate in the right spirit: to invite comments, to accept criticisms, to concede when necessary and, of course, to take praise graciously where credit is due. The intention here should not be for one party to score points over the other, but to complement the functions of each other.

    Yes, let conscience be our guide. The task ahead is not exactly an easy one, and it is not likely that all MPs can fulfil this role successfully. The outspoken Backbencher will certainly not win a popularity poll amongst Ministers and, conversely, the aggressive, short-tempered, arrogant Minister will find himself sipping coffee alone in the Members' Room next door. The challenge, as I see it, is to develop the art of Minister-bashing without tears and to do it in such a way that Ministers ask for more of the same!

    I have gone to some length on this subject because I feel that this is an extremely important matter that demands the attention of all. I salute the leaders who call for greater debate so that different and indeed divergent views can contend. I think it would be suicidal for the PAP and for this Government to continue to think that Singaporeans would readily accept as gospel truth without question, any action or policy of the Government, however well-intentioned it may be; and that every five years the same party would be returned full-house.

    As Singapore prospers, as more and more people are educated with increasing political awareness and sophistication, and as the basic needs like food, shelter, jobs and education are attended to, the battle for people's hearts and allegiance is won through the minds; using reason, logic and persuasion. In the words of Shakespeare, "Your gentleness will move me more than force move me to gentleness". It shall, I feel, better insulate Singapore against attempts to subvert government and people and I think this new approach would be a better bet than

Column: 265

no political opportunists or gamblers come to power by default.

    I have good reasons to believe that the call for greater parliamentary debate is sincere, and well-intentioned. It is timely and it is necessary too.

    May I, therefore suggest that these same leaders now call for debate to be extended outside Parliament with similar exhortations. This is a logical sequel. We must surely agree that there is a near total lack of public debate. People fight shy of uttering opinions, shun controversy for a variety of reasons and I do not propose to go into these reasons here. They act as if politics and affairs of state are taboo, the prerogative of Government leaders and MPs alone, The newspapers, radio and television are devoid of opinions on political issues or Government policies. No, it is not their business to get involved in such matters. Who knows what will happen if you utter the wrong words or espouse the wrong things?

    It seems clear to me that this Government has declared that it will not even put communists and pro-communists behind bars if only they will "denounce the CPM's use of force to seize power, and themselves forswear the use of force to unseat a constitutionally elected government." If this is so, what is there to worry?

    In this context, Sir, I must congratulate the hon. Member for Kampong Chai Chee for starting a monthly Meet-the-People Forum so that his constituents can raise and thrash out any issues on Government policy or implementations. Likewise the mass media, including radio and television, civic organisations and community centres can similarly serve as forum for public debate. MPs and Ministers should participate if invited. It would be a welcome change if the Chairman of the Public Utilities Board participates in a TV forum on PUB charges or the Minister of Defence arguing the case for national service for women on TV against anxious parents, husbands or lovers, or indeed the hon. Member for Telok Blangah

Column: 266

discussing the case for Daylight Saving in Singapore against those who think it utterly irrelevant to Singapore.

3.13 p.m.

    The Senior Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Social Affairs (Mr Chan Chee Song): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to join hon. Members of the House in their support of the President's Address delivered at the opening of the First Session of the Fourth Tuesday, 8th February, 1977.

    In his Address, the President pointed out that our Government has a mandate to reject the soft-headed, pernicious policies that all the good things in life, from bus rides to PUB charges, can be given for free, or otherwise to reduce the fares or charges when the costs are going up. This applies to our social policies which have been formulated with a view to giving a better life to our people.
